div.p: Rossby wave train and source during September–October 2016. a 200 hPa divergent wind anomaly (vectors, scale in upper right, m s −1), Rossby wave source (RWS, magenta contours, positive (anticyclonic) solid and negative (cyclonic) dashed, zero line omitted; interval 4 × 10 −11s −2, see Methods) and outgoing longwave radiation (OLR) anomaly (shading; interval 4 Wm −2) for Sep–Oct 2016. b 200 hPa eddy streamfunction anomaly (shading; interval 3 × 10 6 m 2s) and anomalous wave activity flux (WAF, vectors, m 2 s −2) for Sep–Oct 2016. c– f are same as a, b but displayed fields are derived by multiple linear regression onto the DMI index ( c, d) and Nino34 SST index ( e, f) using historical data for the period 1979–2015 (see Methods). The anomalies in c, d and e, f are scaled by the observed magnitude of the DMI and Nino34 index, respectively, in Sep–Oct 2016. Contouring/shading is as in a and b, except RWS interval is 2 × 10 −11 s −2, and eddy streamfunction interval is 1 × 10 6 m 2s. Anomalies and regression coefficients are shown only for p < 0.10 using two-sided t-test. For clarity, divergent wind weaker than 0.8 ms −1 in a, and weaker than 0.3 ms −1 in c and e, WAF weaker than 0.8 m 2s −2 in b, and weaker than 0.1 m 2s −2 in d and f are masked. In the Southern Hemisphere, negative streamfunction anomaly corresponds to positive geopotential height anomaly and thus is coloured in reds; similarly, positive streamfunction anomaly is coloured in blues. Plots were generated using the NCAR Command Language version 6.4.0 ( www.ncl.ucar.edu)
